Wait. why are all of you calling me miss?
Because the person who goes first is the teacher.
But ... but ... I'm too young to be a teacher. I can't even drive a car yet.
You don't need a car to be a teacher.
All you need is the secret ingredient.
Elina,  is the secret ingredient the power of friendship?
You're close Aaron, but the secret ingredient is even more powerful than the power of friendship.
The secret ingredient is a cat picture!
That's exactly right Kaylee. With a cat picture, you can accomplish anything.
Look. the cat picture says you can do it. that means you can do it Lynn. Because cat pictures never lie.
I can do it! Today, we will learn about comparing fractions.
The trick for comparisons, not just for fractions, but for any type of number,  is to always remember that the bigger number points at the smaller number.
5 is bigger than 3. That's why we write 5 > 3. (pronounced 5 greater than 3) Notice how the arrow points at the 3.
3 is smaller than 100. We write it as 3 < 100. Notice again, how the arrow points at the smaller number.
We are ready to compare fractions!
There are 2 popular methods of doing this. The first method is called decimal conversion. We will turn each fraction into a decimal using long division.
The fractions we will use for our examples are 1/7 and 2/6.
Converting 1/7 into a decimal with long division, we get 0.142857.
And converting 2/6 into a decimal, we get 0.333333.
0.333333 is bigger than 0.142857. That means 2/6 is bigger than 1/7.
That means the final answer is 2/6 > 1/7 because the bigger number points at the smaller number.
Why do we have to learn another way of doing it? Can't we just use decimal conversion for everything?
Decimal conversion will always work for comparing fractions. However, its weakness is that it might take a long time. What if you have weird fractions like 234/487?
Or what if you have 10 fractions and you have to rank them from smallest to biggest? In these situations, decimal conversion won't always the best method.
Which leads us to the second method: common denominator.
The idea in this method, is to normalize each fraction to the same denominator.
Once the denominators are the same, you can basically ignore them and just compare the fractions by looking at the numerator.
For 1/7 and 2/6, the common denominator is 42.
How did you do that Kaylee?
Aaron, do you want the long answer or the short answer?
Okay. The long answer is you find the lowest common multiple between 6 and 7. The short answer is you multiply 6 and 7 together.
Does multiplying them together always work?
To turn denominator 7 into 42, we have to multiply 1/7 by 6/6. That creates the equivalent fraction of 6/42.
And to turn denominator 6 into 42, we have to multiply 2/6 by 7/7. That creates the equivalent fraction of 14/42.
Now that they both have the common denominator of 42, we can ignore the denominator and just compare the numerators.
